story_headline: Rep. Boebert looks to put America first for two more years in Congress
story_copy: Rep. Lauren Boebert (R-Colo.) is running for re-election to continue fighting for Coloradoâ€™s Third District in Congress. Since being sworn into office in January of 2021, Boebert has been both a champion for the â€œSave America Movementâ€ and a staunch opponent of the progressive policies of the Biden administration.We're less than a week out from primary day â€“ votes are already being cast!Help me win this race & continue to fight for our rights. When we're in a majority next year, Biden's agenda is going to screech to a halt!Donate today â€“ help this campaign win!https://t.co/ORFn5nQFslâ€” Lauren Boebert (@laurenboebert) June 23, 2022She has been quick to point out the inconsistencies in Democrat COVID policies such as masking small children in schools, while allowing migrants to flood into the country with a single COVID test or vaccine card. The Republican isnâ€™t just worried about the people coming across the southern border. In order to combat the nationâ€™s leading cause of death for those aged 18 to 45, Boebert has introduced legislation to classify Fentanyl as a weapon of mass destruction.â€œTake my home state of Colorado,â€ said Boebert. â€œIn 2019 there were 222 deaths, in 2020 there were 540 and now in 2021 there were more than 900 fentanyl related deaths. Moms, dads, sons, daughters, fentanyl does not discriminate and we need to take serious steps to combat this.â€Inbox: â€œRep. Lauren Boebert Introduces Legislation to Classify Fentanyl as a Weapon of Mass Destructionâ€ pic.twitter.com/6To6NJrPXhâ€” Adam Kredo (@Kredo0) June 13, 2022Boebert is also an avowed defender of the Second Amendment. The Congresswoman has broken with establishment Republicans by taking the words â€œshall not be infringed upon'â€ literally, as Democrat-backed policies have made the country less safe.â€œWeâ€™re not going to send police to protect you,â€ she voiced. â€œI will not give an inch of the Second Amendment of the rights of the people to keep and bare arms to protect themselves, especially when cries from this chamber are calling to defund law enforcement and our southern border is wide open.â€The firebrand also has a less than conventional way of illustrating what a tyrannical government can do to a defenseless population. Boebert is especially passionate about the Amendment she exercises on the House floor, the right to free speech.The Coloradan has long been a critic of the administrationâ€™s policing of the COVID narrative and the DHSâ€™s persecution of parents at school board meetings. In reaction to Bidenâ€™s so-called disinformation task force, Boebert and her colleagues introduced the â€œProtecting Free Speech Actâ€ to ensure the United States does not follow in the footsteps of Maoist China and Stalinâ€™s Soviet Union.â€œNow is when we the people make our voices heard,â€ The Congresswoman expressed. â€œWe will not accept being called domestic terrorists for showing up to school boards and we sure as hack wonâ€™t allow these Bureaucrats to create a ministry of truth to gaslight the American people.â€President Trump has formally endorsed Rep. Boebertâ€™s re-election campaign. He called her a â€œfearless leaderâ€ and a fighter against â€œloser RINOsâ€ and â€œradical Democrats.â€

story_headline: Gov. Desantis jabs at media for exalting Andrew Gillum
story_copy: Gov. Desantis jabs at media for exalting Andrew GillumFlorida Gov. Ron DeSantis attends a media event regarding the 2022 Florida Python Challenge, Thursday, June 16, 2022, in Miami. (AP Photo/Lynne Sladky)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 12:47 PM PT â€“ Friday, June 24, 2022Governor Ron DeSantis (R-Fla.) forced the media to eat crow after his former opponent was indicted on federal charges. The DOJ charged Democrat Andrew Gillum with 21 counts on Wednesday.On Thursday, DeSantis was asked if he felt vindicated after being called a liar and a racist for bringing up the FBI probe into Gillum during the 2018 gubernatorial race. DeSantis responded by asking the media if they had any type of â€œmea culpaâ€ for glorifying Gillum.â€œThere were clearly a lot of issues there,â€ DeSantis voiced. â€œIf you looked under the hood you saw it. What was presented to the public was that this guy was like the second coming. Never has a candidate been elevated that way by media outlets. Certainly not in the last 10 years or so. I can tell you if I had not won in 2018, this state would be in much worse shape and thatâ€™s not even a question.â€According to the U.S. Attorneyâ€™s Office of the Northern District of Florida, Gillum is facing charges of wire fraud, conspiracy to commit wire fraud and making false statements to the FBI. Gillum served as mayor between 2014 and 2018. The 21 count indictment alleges that the crimes took place between 2016 and 2019, which covers most of the time Gillum was in office.â€œI have spent the last 20 years of my life in public service and continue to fight for the people,â€ Gillum said in a statement. â€œEvery campaign Iâ€™ve run has been done with integrity. Make no mistake that this case is not legal, it is political. Throughout my career I have always stood up for the people of Florida and have spoken truth to power. Thereâ€™s been a target on my back ever since I was the mayor of Tallahassee. They found nothing then, and I have full confidence that my legal team will prove my innocence now.â€Andrew Gillum was indicted for stealing huge amounts of campaign money. This self-serving corruption is what campaign finance laws were passed to stop. I was prosecuted for giving away too much of my own money. Yet the leftists who shriek at me for this are silent about Gillumâ€” Dinesh D'Souza (@DineshDSouza) June 23, 2022Gillum entered rehab in 2020 after police found him in a Miami Beach Hotel with a male prostitute overdosing on drugs. An initial appearance is scheduled for Wednesday at 2 p.m. at the U.S. Courthouse in Tallahassee.
image_caption: Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis attends a media event regarding the 2022 Florida Python Challenge, Thursday, June 16, 2022, in Miami. (AP Photo/Lynne Sladky)

story_headline: Justice Thomas: Reconsider â€˜allâ€™ substantive due process cases
story_copy: Justice Thomas: Reconsider â€˜allâ€™ substantive due process casesFILE â€“ In this Feb. 15, 2018, file photo, Supreme Court Associate Justice Clarence Thomas sits as he is introduced during an event at the Library of Congress in Washington. (AP Photo/Pablo Martinez Monsivais, File)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 2:00 PM PT â€“ Friday, June 24, 2022Justice Clarence Thomas said Dobbs could set precedent to overturn several landmark cases. In his concurring opinion issued on Friday, Thomas said all cases dealing with substantive due process precedents should be reconsidered.â€œIn future cases, we should reconsider all of this Courtâ€™s substantive due process precedents, including Griswold, Lawrence, and Obergefell,â€ voiced Thomas. â€œAny substantive due process decision is demonstrably erroneous. We have a duty to correct the error established in those precedents.â€Thomas mentioned that the three cases are all landmark decisions that established certain constitutional rights. In Griswold v. Connecticut, the court ruled in 1965 that married couples have a right to access contraceptive. In 2003, the court said in Lawrence v. Texas that states could not outlaw consensual gay sex. The Courtâ€™s 2015 decision in Obergefell v. Hodges established a constitutional right to same-sex marriage.He noted cases favoring contraception, same sex marriage and â€œhomosexual conductâ€ could be overturned. This comes after the Supreme Court handed down an opinion overturning Roe v. Wade, arguing the right to an abortion is not a form of liberty under the due process clause of the Fourteenth Amendment.â€œI join the opinion of the Court because it correctly holds that there is no constitutional right to abortion,â€ he said. â€œRespondents invoke one source for that right. The Fourteenth Amendment guarantees that no State shall deprive any person of life, liberty, or property without due process of law. The Court well explains why under our substantive due process precedents the purported right to abortion is not a form of liberty protected by the Due Process Clause. Such a right is neither deeply rooted in this Nationâ€™s history and tradition nor implicit in the concept of ordered liberty.â€In a solo concurring opinion, Thomas says the court should reconsider rulings that protect contraception, same-sex relationships, and same-sex marriage. pic.twitter.com/zcQNko6NVRâ€” Matt Ford (@fordm) June 24, 2022Thomas claimed that it is the duty of the Court to correct these errors.
image_caption: FILE â€“ In this Feb. 15, 2018, file photo, Supreme Court Associate Justice Clarence Thomas sits as he is introduced during an event at the Library of Congress in Washington. (AP Photo/Pablo Martinez Monsivais, File)

story_headline: Biden admin. â€˜disappointedâ€™ in Supreme Court gun ruling
story_copy: Biden admin. â€˜disappointedâ€™ in Supreme Court gun rulingWhite House press secretary Karine Jean-Pierre speaks during the daily briefing at the White House in Washington, Thursday, June 23, 2022. (AP Photo/Susan Walsh)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 10:45 AM PT â€“ Friday, June 24, 2022The Biden administration expressed frustration with the Supreme Courtâ€™s decision allowing Americans to carry handguns in public.â€œWe are disappointed by the Supreme Courtâ€™s ruling,â€ stated Press Secretary Karine Jean Pierre. â€œThe Second Amendment, as youâ€™ve heard the President (Joe Biden) say, is not obsolete and permits common-sense gun regulation.â€In a press briefing Thursday, she said Biden is still calling on individual states to continue enforcing anti-gun policies. She cited New York as an example where a concealed carry law from the year 1911 was upheld by the Department of Justice.â€œAm I disappointedâ€¦Iâ€™ll answer this one question and I was just talking to the governor of New York about this,â€ stated Biden. â€œI am disappointed in the Supreme Court gun decision. There is one little bit of solace in the minority making up the majority opinion has laid out that it effects not every state, it effects only 40 states.â€Republicans have said the Biden administration has no respect for the Supreme Court or other US institutions, adding Democrats seek to impose their own agenda by all means necessary.I'm deeply disappointed by the Supreme Courtâ€™s ruling in New York State Rifle & Pistol Association v. Bruen. This ruling contradicts common sense and the Constitution, and should deeply trouble us all. I remain committed to doing everything in my power to reduce gun violence.â€” Joe Biden (@JoeBiden) June 23, 2022Their remarks came after the US Senate advanced the bipartisan gun reform bill, clearing the way for its full approval by the end of this week. The Senate voted 65 to 34 on Thursday to break a filibuster on the Bipartisan Safer Communities Act, despite concerns it may violate the Second Amendment.â€œThis bipartisan gun safety legislation is progress and will save lives,â€ said Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer (D-N.Y.). â€œWhile it is not everything we want, this legislation is urgently needed.â€The last significant federal gun control legislation was passed in 1994. It banned the manufacture for civilian use of assault rifles and large capacity ammunition clips.The bill will increase background checks for gun buyers under the age of 21. It also closes legal loopholes in buying firearms and will provide funding for mental health programs and security in schools. The blueprint will also call for funding to incentivize states to implement red flag laws to remove firearms from people considered a threat.This comes as the Supreme Court ruled to expand gun rights the same day, allowing Americanâ€™s to carry firearms in public for self defense. However the National Rifle Association,Â  rejected the deal.â€œWe will oppose this gun control legislation because it falls short at every level,â€ the NRA said in a statement. â€œIt does little to truly address violent crime while opening the door to unnecessary burdens on the exercise of Second Amendment freedom by law abiding gun owners.â€Proponents of the bill hope to get it passed before the July recess.
image_caption: White House press secretary Karine Jean-Pierre speaks during the daily briefing at the White House in Washington, Thursday, June 23, 2022. (AP Photo/Susan Walsh)

story_headline: White House to provide additional $450M in aid to Ukraine
story_copy: White House to provide additional $450M in aid to UkraineJohn Kirby, the National Security Council coordinator for strategic communications, speaks during a briefing at the White House in Washington, Thursday, June 23, 2022. (AP Photo/Susan Walsh)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 7:29 AM PT â€“ Friday, June 24, 2022The Biden administration announced an additional $450 million in security assistance to Ukraine. The Department of Defense received the green-light for another draw-down package Thursday to meet the countryâ€™s critical arms needs.The package will include rocket systems, ammunition, grenade launchers and patrol boats. It will also include tactical vehicles, machine guns, spare parts among other equipment.â€œNow this is the thirteenth time that President Biden has authorized a presidential draw-down package during this crisis, bringing the total amount of security assistance that we provided Ukraine to approximately $6.1 billion just since February 24th,â€ stated John Kirby, Coordinator for Strategic Communications for the National Safety Council. â€œApproximately $6.8 billion since the beginning of this administration.â€Â NEW: US has now given over $6 billion in military aid to Ukraine since Russia's full-scale invasionFeb 25: $350mMar 12: $200mMar 16: $800mApr 1: $300mApr 5: $100mApr 13: $800mApr 21: $800mApr 24: $322mMay 6: $100mMay 19: $100mMay 31: $700mJun 15: $1BJun 23: $450mâ€” Jack Detsch (@JackDetsch) June 23, 2022The package being sent to Ukraine will be drawn from existing Defense Department stocks. Kirby confirmed the US plans to continue defense support amid the invasion from Russia. He said President Joe Biden spoke to Ukraine President Volodymyr Zelensky just last week and maintained US support for his countryâ€™s sovereignty and territorial integrity.â€Biden is set to visit Europe next week, with Kirby explaining the President will be announcing news steps to â€œstrengthen European security alongside expected major new contributions from allies.â€ A NATO Summit will be held in Madrid with heads of state from US alliances. This will be an historic gathering an Indo-Pacific leaders from Japan, Australia, New Zealand and the Republic of Korea will be included.
image_caption: John Kirby, the National Security Council coordinator for strategic communications, speaks during a briefing at the White House in Washington, Thursday, June 23, 2022. (AP Photo/Susan Walsh)

story_headline: Chicago guns matter founder praises Supreme Court decision on N.Y. gun law
story_copy: Chicago guns matter founder praises Supreme Court decision on N.Y. gun lawFILE â€“ The Supreme Court is seen at dusk in Washington, D.C. (AP Photo/J. Scott Applewhite, File)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 8:37 AM PT â€“ Friday, June 24, 2022A gun activist in Chicago praised the Supreme Courtâ€™s ruling on a New York law, which restricted the carrying of handguns in public. While speaking to reporters on Thursday, Rhonda Ezell, the founder of the organization Chicago Guns Matter, spoke about the impact the courtâ€™s decision will have on gun rights.Ezell founded the organization after she won an appeal in her federal lawsuit against Chicago over the cityâ€™s ban on gun ranges. Prior to this, the Supreme Court struck down New Yorkâ€™s conceal carry law in a six to three decision.â€œThis means a lot because our rights have been trampled out for decades,â€ said Ezell. â€œEven up to this day, they were still trying to impose more racist gun control measures that does nothing to stop the violence. All they want to do is disarm America for their little utopia of socialism and communism. In this case, here put a stamp onto that, itâ€™s not going to happen and that they have to respect what the Second Amendment is.â€The Second Amendment advocate then went on to describe how she felt about her court victory being referenced during the justiceâ€™s deliberation.â€œSo, for our cases to be cited in this New York state rifle and pistol case, it means a lot to me as much as it does to anyone else in this country,â€ she noted.Â  â€œBut itâ€™s for everyone, itâ€™s for all of us, because itâ€™s going to set a precedent across this nation that we are not standing for tyranny from the political powers that be.â€In the meantime, Ezell spoke about what she has in store for the future of Chicago Guns Matter.â€œIâ€™m looking for someone to invest and bring a gun range in the city of Chicago, so that we can further educate the Black community â€” any community, all communities â€” because we want to get over the stigma of itâ€™s taboo when you talk about firearm ownership in the Black community,â€ she continued.To everyone that likes to talk down on Chicago, today would be a great day to honor the work we've put forth in fighting to keep our freedoms in this country.Real Talk. https://t.co/3XzVYYnCbKâ€” Ms. Ezell (@ms_ezell) June 23, 2022Meanwhile, the Senate passed a bipartisan gun control bill, which incentivizes funding for state red flag laws. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) said she expects the bill to be voted on in the lower chamber before the weekend.
image_caption: FILE â€“ The Supreme Court is seen at dusk in Washington, D.C. (AP Photo/J. Scott Applewhite, File)

story_headline: Biden admin. sends mixed messages on tackling key issues
story_copy: Biden admin. sends mixed messages on tackling key issuesFILE â€“ President Joe Biden speaks at United Performance Metals in Hamilton, Ohio, May 6, 2022. As the challenges confronting Biden intensify, his predictions of a rosy political future for the Democratic Party are growing bolder. (AP Photo/Andrew Harnik, File)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 5:44 PM PT â€“ Thursday, June 23 2022The Biden administration struggled to convince consumers that theyâ€™re really attempting to bring down gas prices. On Thursday, Vice President Kamala Harris claimed officials were working to get gas prices under control.â€œLet me just tell you that the president and I, and our administration, is absolutely committed to doing everything that we can to bring down the cost of gas at the pump,â€ voiced Harris.Â However, President Joe Biden does not seem to be quite as optimistic.â€œThe idea weâ€™re going to be able to click a switch and bring down the cost of gasoline is not likely in the near term,â€ said Biden.Critics recently mocked White House Press Secretary Karine Jean Pierre for saying Biden is doing what he can to â€œalleviateâ€ gas prices.â€œThe President has been very clear in making sure that he does everything he can to alleviate the pain that American families are feeling when it comes to gas prices,â€ the secretary expressed.Despite this, the White House said theyâ€™re going to suspend the federal gas tax for 90 days in an effort to help consumers, which will allow families to feel a little bit of relief. A whole 18 cents per gallon of gas. However, critics have derided the move as they state even former President Barack Obama criticized the idea of a gas tax holiday during his presidential campaign in 2008, calling it a â€œgimmickâ€ at the time.â€œFor us to suggest that 30 cents a day, for 3 months is real relief, that thatâ€™s a real energy policy,â€ stated Obama. â€œIt means that we are not tackling the problem that has to be tackled.â€Additionally, Biden has called on states to provide relief to consumers by suspending the state gas tax, while continuing to blame the conflict in Ukraine for high gas prices and inflation. According to Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell, Ukraine is not the driving force behind rising inflation.â€œGiven how inflation has escalated over the past 18 months, would you say that the word Ukraine is the primary driver of inflation in America,?â€ questioned Powell. â€œNo, inflation was high certainly before the war in Ukraine broke out. Iâ€™m glad to hear you say that the Biden administration seems to be intent on deflecting blame and recently this past Sunday spread the misinformation that Putinâ€™s invasion of Ukraine is the biggest single driver of inflation. Iâ€™m glad that you agree with me thatâ€™s not the truth.â€Critics said the real problem with Bidenâ€™s gas prices and rising inflation are his own policies. A recent poll by I&I and Tipps showed 53 percent of Democrats believe Bidenâ€™s policies are to blame for inflation. Two-thirds of the pollâ€™s respondents showed 66 percent believe too much federal spending has worsened inflation. Somehow despite it all, Biden refuses to take the blame.
image_caption: FILE â€“ President Joe Biden speaks at United Performance Metals in Hamilton, Ohio, May 6, 2022. As the challenges confronting Biden intensify, his predictions of a rosy political future for the Democratic Party are growing bolder. (AP Photo/Andrew Harnik, File)

story_headline: Okla. Gov. Kevin Stitt outlines plan to combat inflation
story_copy: Okla. Gov. Kevin Stitt outlines plan to combat inflationFILE â€“ Oklahoma Gov. Kevin Stitt speaks, April 12, 2022, in Oklahoma City. The Oklahoma Legislature is returning Monday, June 13, to the Capitol for a special session to consider tax cuts the governor wants and how to allocate federal COVID-19 relief funds that were part of the American Rescue Plan Act. (AP Photo/Sue Ogrocki, File)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 1:42 PM PT â€“ Thursday, June 23 2022Oklahoma Governor Kevin Stitt (R) is waiting for the state Senate to pass his inflation relief package as he advocates for real solutions to the Biden inflation crisis. The Governor voiced that he is dedicated to providing Oklahomans relief amid skyrocketing gas prices, high taxes and runaway inflation.He insisted that Oklahomans need â€œrelief right now,â€ not just a check for a tank of gas that will come in December.â€ This comes after Stitt called for a special session of the legislature back in May and demanded more solutions. He said Oklahoma is one of only 13 states taxing groceries and that heâ€™s committed to changing this in his inflation relief package.â€œMy inflation relief plan includes eliminating the state grocery tax and cutting personal income tax for every single Oklahoman,â€ he stated. â€œThis will save the average Oklahoma family $453 each and every year.â€The Governor was endorsed by former President Donald Trump, who also highlighted the Biden administrationâ€™s inability to provide real relief with itâ€™s current budget plan. He reminded Oklahomans they should not have to wait for the Federal Government.â€œThe only tax reform thatâ€™s currently in the budget is motor vehicle tax,â€ the governor uttered. â€œThatâ€™s not real relief. It only helps those who can afford a new car orÂ  truck in the first place. Cutting the new car sales tax does nothing for families who are struggling to afford price for food, gas and everything in between.â€If President Biden really wants to help lower energy costs for Americans, he should stop following the socialist Democratsâ€™ energy playbook and start following Oklahomaâ€™s.My response response to the president's proposal for a three-month federal gas tax holiday: pic.twitter.com/8wESy7MoOvâ€” Governor Kevin Stitt (@GovStitt) June 22, 2022In addition to inflation relief, Stitt said he will always â€œback the blueâ€ and ensure state law enforcement receives a pay increase.â€œSomething Iâ€™m really excited about is pay increases four our law enforcement, he expressed. We will always back the blue in Oklahoma.â€Stitt is now seeking re-election for his second term and his campaign got a major boost. He got backed with the backing of Trump. He called the incumbent Governor a â€œfearless defenderâ€ of the Second Amendment and â€œfighter for the incredible people of Oklahoma.â€
image_caption: FILE â€“ Oklahoma Gov. Kevin Stitt speaks, April 12, 2022, in Oklahoma City. The Oklahoma Legislature is returning Monday, June 13, to the Capitol for a special session to consider tax cuts the governor wants and how to allocate federal COVID-19 relief funds that were part of the American Rescue Plan Act. (AP Photo/Sue Ogrocki, File)

story_headline: Supreme Court rejects N.Y. concealed carry law
story_copy: Supreme Court rejects N.Y. concealed carry lawAnti-scaling fencing is seen outside the Supreme Court, Thursday, June 23, 2022, in Washington. (AP Photo/Jacquelyn Martin)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 11:36 AM PT â€“ Thursday, June 23 2022The Supreme Court issued a ruling striking down New Yorkâ€™s concealed carry law. The decision, released Thursday, had six justices stating it violates the Second Amendment while three dissented. In the majority opinion, Justice Clarence Thomas wrote the stateâ€™s licensure laws are unconstitutional.New York banned the issuance of concealed carry permits unless there is a demonstrable need for self defense, allowing the state to reject most permits. The court has now upheld the right of every American to self defense both on their own property and in public.SCOTUS just struck down New York's concealed carry law! This decision marks a historic, proper, & necessary victory for law abiding NYers, whose 2nd Amendment rights are under constant attack. I was proud to sign onto the Amicus Brief in support of @NYSRPAâ€™s case.â€” Lee Zeldin (@RepLeeZeldin) June 23, 2022New York GOP Rep. Elise Stefanik praised the Supreme Court ruling striking down the state law. In a statement Thursday, she said the court correctly declared the stateâ€™s shameful attempt to shred the Second Amendment of New Yorkers to be unconstitutional.Stefanik also called out the far-left for pushing unconstitutional gun measures as New Yorkâ€™s failed bail reform policies have made communities more unsafe. She contended the courtâ€™s ruling allows gun owners in the Empire State and across the nation to exercise their constitutional right to concealed carry.ğŸš¨ğŸš¨The Supreme Court has ruled against New York Stateâ€™s attack on #2A rightsğŸš¨ğŸš¨My full statementâ¬‡ï¸ pic.twitter.com/0zDGJHTdlMâ€” Rep. Elise Stefanik (@RepStefanik) June 23, 2022The courts decision came shortly after the Senate advanced an 80-page gun bill. On Tuesday, 14 Republicans, including Minority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.), joined Democrats to push the bill to debate in a 64-to-34 vote.The bill includes enhanced background checks for those under 21, funding for mental health and school safety, incentives for states to implement red flag laws and limits on the so-called boyfriend loophole. The Senate is looking to pass the gun reform package before summer recess, which begins July 4.
image_caption: Anti-scaling fencing is seen outside the Supreme Court, Thursday, June 23, 2022, in Washington. (AP Photo/Jacquelyn Martin)

story_headline: Va. Gov. Youngkin seeks ban on most abortions at 15 weeks
story_copy: Va. Gov. Youngkin seeks ban on most abortions at 15 weeksVirginia Gov. Glenn Youngkin speaks prior to signing the budget at a ceremony at a grocery store Tuesday June 21, 2022, in Richmond, Va. (AP Photo/Steve Helber)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 6:00 PM PT â€“ Saturday, June 25, 2022Virginia Governor Glenn Youngkin (R) vowed to find middle ground when it comes to the issue of abortion. On Friday, Youngkin spoke to the Washington Post and said heâ€™ll push an abortion ban after 15 weeks. He admitted the divided state legislature would likely pass a ban after 20 weeks. Youngkin asked four Virginia lawmakers who are all anti-abortion Republicans to craft legislation.â€œVirginians elected a pro-life governor and he supports finding consensus on legislation,â€ Youngkin spokesperson Macaulay Porter said in a statement. â€œHe has tapped Senator Siobhan Dunnavant, Senator Steve Newman, Delegate Kathy Byron and Delegate Margaret Ransone to do so and prioritize protecting life when babies begin to feel pain in the womb, including a 15 week threshold.â€My statement on Supreme Courtâ€™s Dobbs Ruling Announcement: pic.twitter.com/JA6N2UGDxiâ€” Governor Glenn Youngkin (@GovernorVA) June 24, 2022Youngkin welcomed the high courtâ€™s ruling as an â€œappropriateâ€ return of power to the states. Youngkinâ€™s policy announcement is his most explicit policy statement to date. This was an issue that he tried to avoid during last yearâ€™s campaign. It only seemed to aggravate the partisan divide.â€œVirginians do want fewer abortions as opposed to more abortions,â€ Youngkin voiced. â€œI am not someone who is going to jump in and try to push us apart, there is a place we can come together.â€In D.C. and Maryland Democratic leaders criticized the ruling and pledged to safeguard abortion access rights. Maryland Gov. Larry Hogan (R) said via email that his state passed laws 30 years ago to protect access to abortion.â€œI swore an oath to uphold the Constitution and the laws of Maryland,â€ Hogan declared. That is what I have always done and will continue to do as governor.â€Youngkin added that he supports exceptions for rape, incest and if the motherâ€™s life is in danger

story_headline: Biden signs bipartisan gun control bill into law
story_copy: Biden signs bipartisan gun control bill into lawPresident Joe Biden signs into law S. 2938, the Bipartisan Safer Communities Act gun safety bill, in the Roosevelt Room of the White House in Washington, Saturday, June 25, 2022. (AP Photo/Pablo Martinez Monsivais)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 1:15 PM PT â€“ Saturday, June 25, 2022President Joe Biden signed the most sweeping gun control bill in decades. On Saturday, Biden said while the bill doesnâ€™t have everything he wanted, it includes actions heâ€™s long called for that are going to save lives.â€œLives will be saved,â€ the President said. â€œTheir message to us was to do something. Well today, we did.â€The house passed a compromise made by a group of bipartisan Senators on Friday, which included enhanced background checks for buyers under 21 and provides federal funding for states to implement â€œRed Flagâ€ laws. Biden signed the measure two days after the Supreme Courtâ€™s ruling struck down a New York law that restricted peopleâ€™s ability to carry concealed weapons.I just signed into law the Bipartisan Safer Communities Act. While this bill doesn't do everything I want it to, it does include actions that I've long called for that will save lives.Today, we acted for the families that have lost their souls to an epidemic of gun violence. pic.twitter.com/QWg3orWuS1â€” President Biden (@POTUS) June 25, 2022â€œFrom Columbine to Sandy Hook to Charleston, Orlando, Las Vegas, Parkland, El Paso, Atlanta, Buffalo, Uvalde,â€ Biden voiced. â€œFor the shootings that happen every day in the streets that are mass shootings we donâ€™t even hear about.â€It also gets rid of the so called â€œboyfriend loophole,â€ prohibiting those convicted of domestic abuse from owing a firearm. Most of the $13 billion cost will help bolster mental health programs and aid schools, which have been targeted in Newtown, Connecticut, Parkland, Florida and elsewhere in mass shootings.Tune in as I sign into law S. 2938, the Bipartisan Safer Communities Act, and deliver remarks on reducing gun violence and saving lives. https://t.co/evfofKN84eâ€” President Biden (@POTUS) June 25, 2022â€œI know thereâ€™s much more work to do,â€ he stated. â€œIâ€™m never going to give up, but this is a monumental day.â€The new law does not include tougher restrictions long championed by Democrats, such as a ban on assault style weapons and background checks for all gun transactions. However, it is the most impactful firearms violence measure produced by Congress since enactment of a long expired assault weapons ban in 1993.Biden went on to say he will host an event for lawmakers and families affected by gun violence on July 11.TOPICS:boyfriend loopholegun lawsJill BidenJoe Bidenmass shootingmental healthnewsnewtonOANOANNuvaldeWhite House SHARETWEETPINSHARE
image_caption: President Joe Biden signs into law S. 2938, the Bipartisan Safer Communities Act gun safety bill, in the Roosevelt Room of the White House in Washington, Saturday, June 25, 2022. (AP Photo/Pablo Martinez Monsivais)

story_headline: Rep. Tenney runs for re-election to take on Big Tech
story_copy: Rep. Tenney runs for re-election to take on Big TechFILE PHOTO: 3D-printed images of the logos of Facebook and parent company Meta Platforms are seen on a laptop keyboard in this illustrationOAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 3:15 PM PT â€“ Saturday, June 25, 2022A fighter for election integrity is running to keep her Congressional seat. Rep. Claudia Tenney (R-N.Y.) is running for re-election to represent New Yorkâ€™s 24th Congressional District.Tenney voted against all tax increases while sheâ€™s held office. She represented upstate New York in the state assembly and sponsored legislation to eliminate the state personal income tax. The Congresswoman is best known for being a fighter for transparency at the voting polls and launched the election integrity caucus. She has a background as an attorney and business owner. The Republican also co-chairs the caucus, where she brings to the table her experience of winning her 2020 election despite Democrat partisan meddling by Anthony Brindisi (D-N.Y.).ğŸš¨ #NY24 AD ALERT ğŸš¨To raise a future Marine as a single mother while running a small business at the same time â€“ I had to be tough!To take on liberal Democrats and weak-kneed Republicans in Albany â€“ I had to be tenacious!  See more below ğŸ“ºğŸ‘‡ pic.twitter.com/H7dvzBvnpqâ€” Claudia Tenney (@claudiatenney) June 14, 2022She has been at the forefront of defeating three ballot propositions that would have impacted election integrity. He called her a fantastic Rep. and said she will continue to fight for the America First agenda.It was great to join President Trump and @EliseStefanik! The #RedWave is coming to New York.Iâ€™m honored to have President Trumpâ€™s strong endorsement. In Congress, I stood with him to put America First. I will always fight for our Upstate values. #NY24 pic.twitter.com/EVXHvOJLL8â€” Claudia Tenney (@claudiatenney) June 8, 2022

story_copy: Vermont Police attacked with excavatorPARK CITY, KS â€“ FEBRUARY 26: Police tape hangs across the street in front of the house that Dennis Rader lives in February 26, 2005 in Park City, Kansas. (Photo by Larry W. Smith/Getty Images)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 7:30 PM PT â€“ Saturday, June 25, 2022The parents of burglary suspect are in custody after they impeded their sonâ€™s arrest. Tallmanâ€™s parents tried to stop officers from arresting their son as Troopers Skylar Velasquez and Gabe Schrauf arrived at the scene.â€œThey donâ€™t have a scenario at the academy where we practice this one,â€ stated Matt Dalley, Vermont State Police Capt.Dashcam footage shows Vermont State Police attempting to arrest 24-year-old Brandon Tallman on burglary and assault charges. The suspectâ€™s mom Amy Tallman got into a scuffle with the arresting officers, while the suspectâ€™s dad Wayne Tallman lowered the boom of an excavator and swung the bucket at the troopers. While Daley was not there that day, he said the troopers made good decisionsâ€œIt was a dangerous situation that you guys were put in,â€ Capt. Daley said. â€œIn the end you came out on top. You effected the arrest. You guys both came home that night and thatâ€™s the goal of why we went there.â€Â Last week, two troopers found themselves in an unexpected and dangerous situation when they went to a home in Hardwick to arrest a suspect in an assault and burglary case. Thankfully, this incident ended with the subjects in custody, and no injuries to anyone involved. pic.twitter.com/TqnGvm71Pxâ€” Vermont State Police (@VTStatePolice) June 23, 2022Brandon Tallman pleaded not guilty to charges and was released on bail. His is dad Wayne Tallman is being held without bail on charges, including attempted second degree murder. The wife faces charges for impeding an officer.

story_headline: D.C. Police on high alert after abortion ruling
story_copy: D.C. Police on high alert after abortion rulingKiki Fox, 34, of Washington, who is 8 months pregnant, poses for a portrait as she joins abortion rights demonstrators, Saturday, May 14, 2022, outside the Supreme Court in Washington, during protests across the country. (AP Photo/Jacquelyn Martin)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 3:41 PM PT â€“ Saturday, June 25, 2022Police in the Nationâ€™s Capital are hoping for the best, but preparing for the worst in the wake of the Supreme Courtâ€™s decision regarding abortion. Officers in Washington, D.C. were â€œfully activatedâ€ on Friday,Â  many of them outfitted in riot gear just in case things got out of hand.#NEW @DCPoliceDept fully activating in response to #SCOTUS abortion decision @fox5dc https://t.co/jAluqh99cO pic.twitter.com/HPMDBgz0yIâ€” Stephanie Ramirez (@RamirezReports) June 24, 2022Protestors and others waited outside the court for this historic rulingÂ  to be released on Friday morning. Hundreds of protestors were still outside the high court as the sun set, banging drums, leading chants and for the most part they remained peaceful. President Biden urged â€œpeacefulâ€ protests. He said that â€œviolence is never acceptable.â€â€œWe must stand against violence in any form, regardless of your rationale,â€ he said.On way to the court pic.twitter.com/XrE9ExAzhmâ€” Manu Raju (@mkraju) June 24, 2022Former President Barack Obama was quick to condemn the Republican led court and former President Donald Trump for their role in overturning the nearly 50-year-old Supreme Court decision. The mayor of DC held a press conference addressing the matter.â€œThe Chief of Police has been working in close coordination with our federal partners as well to make sure that we are providing MPD support around the courthouse and other sensitive areas,â€ said Mayor Muriel Bowser. â€œWe are also. We stand ready to deal with any First Amendment demonstrations.â€The full departmental activation will extend through the end of the third watch on Tuesday, June 28.

story_headline: Truck plows into pro-choice protesters in Iowa
story_copy: Truck plows into pro-choice protesters in IowaAbortion-rights protesters cheer at a rally, Friday, June 24, 2022, in Des Moines, Iowa. (AP Photo/Charlie Neibergall)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 5:11 PM PT â€“ Saturday, June 25, 2022A truck rammed through a group of pro-choice protesters in Iowa. The incident took place at an abortion rights rally in Cedar Rapids on Friday and police confirmed at least one person was injured.The group was made up of mostly women protesters that were demonstrating against the Supreme Court ruling that overturned Roe v. Wade, when an unidentified man driving a black Ford truck drove into them.Footage showed bystanders hitting the truck to make it stop after witnesses said the unidentified driver grew impatient. Local journalist and author Lyz Lenz said the suspect swerved around several other vehicles to hit female protesters in the crosswalk.â€œIâ€™m still in shock a little. I saw a man try to kill two women while his wife screamed and told him to stop,â€Â  said Lyz Lenz.A truck driver plowed through multiple pro-choice protesters in Cedar Rapids, Iowa on Friday, sending at least one woman to the hospital. Video provided by Linn County Supervisor Stacey Walker shows several victims â€” all women â€” trying to stop the driver as he careens into them pic.twitter.com/jcGTcfcK8Xâ€” Andy Campbell (@AndyBCampbell) June 25, 2022Protestor Alexis Russell described the truck driver as â€œa gray-haired white male dude, probably in his 50s or 60s.â€ She said she tried to stop the truck by grabbing the steering wheel, fell over, and was injured when the driver sped off. She was later hospitalized.â€œI think he wanted to hurt me when he sped off,â€ stated Russell. â€œI landed on my butt and it really hurts. My lower back, my inner thighs and hamstring.â€Meantime, police have yet to make an arrest.

story_headline: Wis. Planned Parenthood to pause abortions until clarification on state law
story_copy: Wis. Planned Parenthood to pause abortions until clarification on state lawAbortion rights supporters gather for a â€œpink outâ€ protest organized by Planned Parenthood in the rotunda of the state Capitol Wednesday, June 22, 2022, in Madison, Wis. (AP Photo/Harm Venhuizen)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 2:35 PM PT â€“ Friday, June 24, 2022Planned Parenthood in Wisconsin paused operations until they get clarification on the stateâ€™s law. Planned Parenthood of Wisconsin President Tanya Atkinson announced the decision to halt abortions at their clinics on Friday, following the Supreme Courtâ€™s reversal of Roe v. Wade.â€œThis ruling takes away the freedom to control our bodies and personal health care decisions, giving it to politicians to decide,â€ Atkinson said in a statement after the decision was announced.PPAWI President Tanya Atkinson reacts to the US Supreme Court decision to overturn Roe v. Wade. pic.twitter.com/5NQRNrZz2Câ€” Planned Parenthood Advocates of Wisconsin (@PPAWI) June 24, 2022The ruling devolves power back to the states, which re-establishes criminal penalties for abortion providers in Wisconsin. In Wisconsin, that means a statute passed in 1849 that created penalties with no exceptions made for cases of rape or incest.Last month, Planned Parenthood of Wisconsin also said it planned to work with the organizationâ€™s Illinois chapter to arrange for abortion services in that state, where it is still legal up to the point of the fetus being considered viable.â€œAlthough abortion services are not available in Wisconsin for now, Planned Parenthoodâ€™s doors across the state are open and we are here to help patients get the care they need,â€ the PPH President voiced. â€œThis includes helping patients access safe abortion care where it remains legal, offering travel assistance and providing appropriate follow-up care when they return home. Your health and the health of the community is our number one priority.â€The Wisconsin Attorney General has vowed to not enforce penalties for administering abortions and has called on other law enforcement agencies to follow suit. 26 states are expected to restrict abortion access in response to the verdict.
image_caption: Abortion rights supporters gather for a â€œpink outâ€ protest organized by Planned Parenthood in the rotunda of the state Capitol Wednesday, June 22, 2022, in Madison, Wis. (AP Photo/Harm Venhuizen)

story_headline: 26 states expected to enforce stricter abortion laws following SCOTUS decision to overturn Roe v. Wade
story_copy: 26 states expected to enforce stricter abortion laws following SCOTUS decision to overturn Roe v. WadeAnti-abortion protesters celebrate following Supreme Courtâ€™s decision to overturn Roe v. Wade, federally protected right to abortion, outside the Supreme Court in Washington, Friday, June 24, 2022. The Supreme Court has ended constitutional protections for abortion that had been in place nearly 50 years, a decision by its conservative majority to overturn the courtâ€™s landmark abortion cases. (AP Photo/Gemunu Amarasinghe)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 7:45 AM PT â€“ Friday, June 24, 2022The Supreme Court announced its decision in the case of Dobbs v. Jackson, officially overturning the half century precedent Roe v. Wade. That vote came down Friday morning In a six-to-three decision.This landmark case challenged the constitutionality of a 2018 Mississippi state law that bans most abortion operations after the first 15-weeks of pregnancy. This decision came after Politico published a leaked draft opinion last month, which indicated the Supreme Court was set to overturn Roe v. Wade the 1973 case that established a federal right to an abortion.Now, in a post-Roe America, states will be free to set their own abortion standards and over a dozen states will immediately ban the procedure outright. Tensions were high outside the Supreme Court ahead of the decision with protesters on both sides of the argument battling. Police officers formed a wall with bicycles and motorcycles in an attempt to calm tensions outside.Pro-abortion activists chant â€œPro-life is a lie, they donâ€™t care if children dieâ€ in the face of pro-life protesters outside SCOTUS @OANN pic.twitter.com/lil3Y2OHPTâ€” Daniel Baldwin (@baldwin_daniel_) June 24, 2022With abortion protections ending following the high courts decision, 26 states are expected to tighten abortion restrictions in the wake of the landmark supreme court decision.
image_caption: Anti-abortion protesters celebrate following Supreme Courtâ€™s decision to overturn Roe v. Wade, federally protected right to abortion, outside the Supreme Court in Washington, Friday, June 24, 2022. The Supreme Court has ended constitutional protections for abortion that had been in place nearly 50 years, a decision by its conservative majority to overturn the courtâ€™s landmark abortion cases. (AP Photo/Gemunu Amarasinghe)
